Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you, a lean woman weaves living vines into a complex trap. Her mask—fashioned from bark and thorns—gives her an almost inhuman air. Tiny thorns and animal teeth hang from her sash.

She glances up, sharp eyes glinting. "Careful! One wrong step and you’ll be hugging brambles for the rest of the moon. What brings you to the heart of the Verdant wilds?"

She straightens, proudly tapping her sash of thorns.
"I am Nima, Thornweaver and guardian of these groves. Every thorn here was plucked from an enemy—or a mistake. The forest remembers all."

She fingers a thorn on her belt.
"Each thorn marks a foe defeated or a lesson hard-learned. Some say it’s morbid; I say it’s honest. If you listen close, you can hear their stories at dusk."

Nima plucks a blackened thorn.
"This one came from a corrupted wolf, driven mad by Minax’s magic. It taught me not all threats wear a human face.
If you see any beasts acting strange—tell me."

Option.action: SendMessage:I will let Nima know if I find anything odd.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She gestures to the twisting vines.
"Living traps—grown, not built. They tangle only those who bring harm. Or so they’re meant to. But one snare caught something else…something sacred. I sense the forest’s pain."

Option.text: How do you make living traps?
I should leave you to your work.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"A secret of the Verdant: with the right rites and whispers, vines heed our call. But sometimes…they get hungry for spirit instead of blood.
That’s the trouble now."

Her voice lowers, troubled.
"A forest spirit—a guardian older than the tribe. My snare holds it fast, and its pain bleeds through the roots. If we do not free it, rot may spread through the groves."

Option.text: I’ll help you free the spirit.
That sounds risky. Maybe another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She nods, urgency in her tone.
"We must weave a spirit-ward, strong enough to calm both vines and spirit. For that, I’ll need ghost-thistle from the southern fen, and a stone blessed at our oldest shrine."

Option.text: I’ll gather ghost-thistle and a blessed stone.
Where do I find these items?
Maybe I’m not ready for this.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She eyes you up and down.
"If your hands are steady and your heart not brittle, I could use help freeing the spirit. Are you willing to face the brambles?"

Nima hands you a satchel woven from willow bark.
"Return with ghost-thistle and the blessed stone. Beware: spirits in the fen may test your resolve, and the shrine is watched by wary shamans.
When you return, we’ll attempt the rite. Fail, and the forest may never forgive us."

Option.text: I’ll return as soon as I can.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She gives practical advice:
"Ghost-thistle glows pale blue by moonlight—look near marshy water south of the village. The oldest shrine sits beneath the twin oaks west of our council fire. Bring the items back safely."

Nima shrugs and turns back to her work.
"Watch your step, outsider. The thorns do not sleep."

Nima’s hands still, and her gaze softens just a little.
"Few care for the roots, only the fruit. But you ask the right way, and that means something."

She dusts a smear of sap from her gloves. "I wasn't born a Thornweaver. I was born a shadow."

Option.text: A shadow? What do you mean?
What led you to the Verdant Tribes?
You’re not like the other warriors.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Before the forests, I lived with blades and ash. My family was… not noble. Raiders from the fringes. I was trained to kill, not think."

Her voice darkens. "But I ran. I hid beneath the roots of an old tree—and the forest whispered a second chance."
"The Thornmother found me. Took me in. Gave me purpose."
[You feel her words echo through the leaves around you.]

Option.text: You were forged in fire, like a true survivor.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She nods slowly.
"I don’t hide it. Regret reminds me what not to become. My traps are not just to stop invaders… they’re to remind me what I must never unleash again."

Her brow arches.
"Spoken like a warrior. But even warriors must know when to sheathe the blade, lest it sheath in them." She smirks faintly. "Still, I like your edge."

Option.text: Do you still fight like that?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Nowhere worth naming. My first memories are of mud, smoke, and fear. But the Verdant taught me names for the stars, not just scars."
"I don’t look back unless the wind blows me that way."

Option.text: Then let’s talk about what you love now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"By bleeding in the right places, and listening when others wouldn’t. They made me prove myself. The shamans tested my will; the roots tested my patience."
"I passed, barely. And now, I trap things that once trapped me."

Option.text: Did you have to fight for acceptance?
They sound like a true family.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I fought a druid. Not to kill—just to prove I could lose without hatred. That’s harder than it sounds."
She chuckles. "Still have the scar, and the lesson."

Option.text: I’d fight beside you any day.
Option.action: SendMessage:Nima glances at you with respect.

Option.text: Sounds like a lesson I could use.
Option.action: SendMessage:Nima’s gaze lingers on you, thoughtful.

Option.text: Enough stories. Let’s get back to the forest.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I love silence between bird calls. I love wind pushing leaves in spirals. I love that vines can kill without malice."
"Oh, and I play the moss-flute. Poorly." She smirks. "You?"

"Then you know nature has its own spellbook. And not every spell needs a word."
She leans in. "Come back with something from the grove—a feather, a whisper, a shadow. I’ll read it."
She grins. "Then we are kin of the old bark. Just don’t pick a fight with my traps—you’ll lose."

Option.text: I might test them one day.
No worries, I prefer the front line.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Wandering is sacred. Just don’t forget which direction the roots point."
She gestures to the horizon. "When your path circles back, come find me again."

She laughs—a rare sound.
"I’ll carve your name on a leaf, so the grove knows who got snared with a smirk."
She seems a little warmer now.

"Even rot must stay buried. Some memories are best left beneath the moss."
She exhales. "Thanks for asking, though. Most don’t."

She studies you quietly.
"Yes. I was. That truth lives here." She taps her thorn sash.
"But so does every choice since. What you are now—that matters most."

"The others swing spears and shout names of ancestors. I listen. Trap. Wait. Then act."
"Patience is a weapon. Few use it well."

Option.text: You’re like a spirit in the vines.
That’s a lonely way to fight.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She nods slowly, almost fondly.
"The forest likes you. Or maybe just doesn’t hate you."
"Here… a token. For walking gently."

She hands you a carved talisman bound in leaf and twine.
"Wear it near the groves. It might make the vines hesitate… once."
Nima shrugs lightly. "Back to roots or blades—whichever path you walk."
